abstract.p: Long-read sequencing has emerged as a powerful tool for uncovering novel transcripts and genes. However, existing protocols often lack confidence in identifying the transcription start site (TSS) and fail to capture non-poly(A) RNA, thereby limiting the discovery of novel genes, particularly long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs). In this study, we introduce Cap-trap full-length cDNA sequencing (CFC-seq), a comprehensive protocol that combines Cap-trapping and poly(A)-tailing with Oxford Nanopore sequencing. This protocol enables precise identification of TSSs and full-length transcripts. Applying CFC-seq to two in vitro differentiation time courses resulted in approximately 236 million mappable reads. The transcript Start-site Aware Long-read Assembler (SALA) was developed for de novo assembling the transcript models, leading to the identification of 39,425 confident novel genes. Using this dataset, enhancer-derived ncRNAs were re-defined with longer length and more splicing activity, which were correlated with enhancer structure. Compared to enhancers with CpG islands, TATA box enhancers were shown to be more cell type specific with fewer chromatin interaction but produced longer and more stable polyadenylated RNA. A significant proportion of these TATA box-derived eRNAs originated from LTR transposable elements. Overall, this study systematically annotated ~24,000 novel eRNA genes and correlated their transcription properties with enhancer structure.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the human genome, pervasive transcription results in primary transcripts covering 75% of the genome, yet only 2% contributes to protein coding (Djebali et al. 2012). Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are the major product of such pervasive transcription. In contrast to ~20,000 protein coding genes, at least 95,000 lncRNA genes have been identified (Li et al. 2023). Notably, the transcript models of these lncRNAs are mainly constructed by assembling short-read RNA-seq data (Iyer et al. 2015; You et al. 2017; Hon et al. 2017; Jiang et al. 2019). The application of long-read sequencing has proven invaluable in accurately delineating the transcripts of lncRNA (Lagarde et al. 2017; Carbonell Sala et al. 2021). Various long-read protocols have been established to discover novel transcripts (Garalde et al. 2018; Sharon et al. 2013; Pardo-Palacios et al. 2024; Glinos et al. 2022; Uapinyoying et al. 2020). These studies primarily focused on identifying novel isoforms from the annotated gene loci instead of novel genes. Indeed, evidence of independent transcription revealed by CAP-trap protocol provides extra confidence in novel gene identification. Unlike protein coding genes, lncRNAs are usually lowly-expressed and often transcribed from the body of another gene. Detection of an accurate transcription start site (TSS) from the long-read sequencing is important to distinguish them from the genes in the same loci and confirm their independent transcription. Additionally, substantial lncRNA candidates are often excluded from standard long-read protocols which adopt poly-dT priming, due to their lack of a poly(A) tail. Therefore, a tailored protocol of long-read sequencing for lncRNAs is needed to comprehensively annotate them in the human genome.

From the approximately one million cis regulatory elements (CREs) predicted from the human genome (The ENCODE Project Consortium et al. 2020), more than 95% of them were enhancer-like. This suggested that enhancer-derived lncRNAs (eRNAs) represent the majority of lncRNAs. While the activity of enhancers is well-investigated (Field and Adelman 2020; Claringbould and Zaugg 2021), non-negligible functional roles of eRNAs have also been identified (Arner et al. 2015; Alvarez-Dominguez et al. 2017; Aguilo et al. 2016; Nair et al. 2019; Gorbovytska et al. 2022). In order to facilitate the functional studies on the RNA derived from enhancers, defining their gene and transcript models is necessary. Genome wide identification of enhancers or CREs is multifaceted (Panigrahi and O’Malley 2021), approaches relying on chromatin state such as H3K27Ac and/or H3K4me1 (The ENCODE Project Consortium et al. 2020), chromatin accessibility showed by DNase or ATAC-seq (Zhang et al. 2021) and the act of transcription revealed by 5’ end sequencing (Arner et al. 2015; Hirabayashi et al. 2019; Kristjánsdóttir et al. 2020; Moody et al. 2022) are applied independently or integratively. When identifying enhancers by their acts of transcription, it is essential to distinguish the genuine TSS of the transcripts from technical noise. Thus, a long-read sequencing strategy that identifies enhancers with accurate 5’ends and characterises the eRNAs simultaneously is crucial in identifying novel eRNAs.

Since widespread transcription was observed from enhancers (Kim et al. 2010), transcriptional properties of eRNA have been explored by multiple studies. In general, canonical eRNAs refer to short, non-polyadenylated, unspliced, m7G-capped transcripts that are bi-directionally transcribed (2D) from enhancers (Andersson et al. 2014; Kim et al. 2010; Schwalb et al. 2016). Unidirectional (1D) eRNAs (often referred as enhancer-associated lncRNAs) were also identified and they are often longer, spliced and polyadenylated (De Santa et al. 2010; Vučićević et al. 2015; Gil and Ulitsky 2018). While transcribed 2D enhancers were shown to have less CpG islands (CGI) than promoters (Andersson et al. 2014), chromatin state-defined enhancers were observed with high GC content (Xiong et al. 2018) and functionally cooperate with proximal CGI (Pachano et al. 2021). For non-polyadenylated eRNAs, the termination of the transcripts depends on the integrator complex (Lai et al. 2015; Lykke-Andersen et al. 2021; Welsh and Gardini 2023). Early termination mediated by WDR82, PNUTS/PP1 and SET1 was also reported to control the termination of eRNAs (Austenaa et al. 2015). The half-life of eRNAs is as short as a few minutes (Schwalb et al. 2016) and are subjected to degradation by the nuclear exosome (Pefanis et al. 2015). Therefore, more eRNAs are detected via sequencing nascent transcripts (Schwalb et al. 2016) or chromatin-bound RNA (Hirabayashi et al. 2019).

Here, we developed the CFC-seq protocol for sampling full-length cDNA by adopting Cap-trapping and poly(A)-tailing (PAT) on the Oxford Nanopore technologies (ONT) platform (Fig. 1a). We observed the Cap-trap features, including 5’ un-encoded G from the reads while these features allow us to identify genuine transcription start sites (TSSs) and transcribed cis-regulatory elements (tCREs) from the long-read sequencing. In vitro poly(A)-tailing of total RNA increased the sampling of eRNAs and lncRNAs without a natural poly(A) tail. This protocol identifies TSSs and transcript models derived from the same molecules simultaneously. Thereafter, we investigated the transcriptional properties of non-coding RNAs derived from their specific promoters and enhancers. These properties correlated with the enhancer structure including the presence of CGI and TATA box. While the relatively ubiquitous CGI enhancers generate shorter and more exosome-sensitive RNAs, TATA box derived eRNAs are longer, more stable, frequently spliced and polyadenylated. More than 27% of these TATA box-derived eRNAs are originated from long terminal repeats (LTR) retrotransposons. TATA box was shown to be depleted from the transcribed super enhancer (SE) and 2D enhancer, leading to less spliced eRNAs observed from SE and 2D enhancers. Overall, CFC-seq enabled annotation of eRNA transcript models, while the transcription of these models was correlated with the heterogeneity of the enhancer structure.

sec.title: CFC-seq shows the best TSS coverage and samples non-poly(A) RNA
sec.p: We developed the CFC-seq protocol by combining Cap-trap technology and PAT with the ONT long-read cDNA sequencing (Fig. 1a). After the pre-processing of the CFC-seq data, 236 million mappable reads were obtained from the 5 cell-types (Fig. 1b & Ext1a). We first explored the 5’ end completeness of the CAP trapping-based CFC-seq. Compared with other long-read protocols collected by ENCODE on the same iPS line (WTC11), CFC-seq showed the highest percentage of reads starting from the SCREEN cCRE regions, chromatin-open regions revealed by ATC-seq and FANTOM5 CAGE clusters (Fig. 1c). These results demonstrated the effectiveness of the Cap-trap technology in sampling RNAs with complete 5’ ends, which reflect the TSSs. On the other hand, PAT was incorporated into the protocol to capture non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) devoid of a natural poly(A) tail, by enzymatically adding a stretch of adenines to the 3’ end of the extracted RNA. To address the coverage of non-poly(A) RNA, we performed CFC-seq with or without PAT in THP-1. As PAT allowed the protocol to reveal non-poly(A) RNA molecules, a considerable fraction of the library comprised known non-poly(A) genes including histone genes and small nucleolar RNA, suggesting the effectiveness of the PAT (Ext_Fig. 1b). Internal priming was known to occur in poly-dT priming protocol by binding to the adenine-rich sequence on the RNA body (Svoboda et al. 2022). We estimated the potential of internal priming of all the sampled 3’ ends according to the percentage of downstream adenines (Fig. 1d). After excluding known non-poly(A) genes and reads potentially captured by internal priming, ~98% of mRNA reads without PAT carry a poly(A) signal (PAS) motif (Fig. 1e), suggesting poly-dT priming in CFC-seq capture full-length molecules effectively. From the protocol with PAT on THP-1, 96%, 80% and 55% of reads derived from mRNA, promoter-derived ncRNAs and enhancer-derived ncRNAs respectively contain the PAS motif. Therefore, CFC-seq captures non-poly(A) RNAs and many of them are non-coding.

Around 4% of the mRNA reads from the PAT protocol were found lacking a PAS motif (Fig. 1e). We reasoned that they are the nascent RNAs and identified the location of these captured 3’ ends from the coding gene fraction (Ext_Fig. 1c). Initially, we explored the mRNA content from the libraries without performing PAT which represents the technical limitation of a poly-dT protocol. From the 2% mRNA reads without a PAS motif, ~28% of these 3’ ends are consistent with the 3’ ends of GENCODE transcripts, suggesting that these RNAs may acquire the poly(A) tail through less conserved PAS motifs or non-canonical pathways. The other 72% potentially resulted from internal priming at a subthreshold level of downstream adenine nucleotides (Ext_Fig. 1d upper). To assess the side effects of including PAT, we subtracted the 3’ ends that were captured by the non-PAT THP-1 libraries from the PAT THP-1 libraries. These PAT-specific 3’ ends constitute about 2% of the libraries according to the coding gene fraction. They are independent from internal priming (Ext_Fig. 1d lower) and were dispersed across the transcript body revealing a relatively higher frequency at the donor sites (Ext_Fig. 1e), resembling nascent RNA along the RNA processing pathway. Next, we determined if including PAT increased the ncRNA content. Comparing the lncRNAs sampled from the non-PAT and PAT THP-1 libraries at the read-level, the fraction of lncRNAs increased from 8% to 13% (Ext_Fig. 1f). Using the raw output from SALA, 25,612 ncRNA gene models are uniquely identified from the PAT library, versus only 6,963 from the non-PAT library (Ext_Fig. 1g). Overall, PAT incorporation increased the ncRNA content and successfully sampled non-poly(A) RNAs which are mainly ncRNAs, with a side effect of introducing ~2% of reads from the transcriptionally incomplete nascent RNAs.

sec.title: PAS motif and random forest comprehensively annotate the 3’ end
sec.p: To quantitatively assess canonical PolII termination events from the transcript models, we introduced a sequence-based random forest classifier trained on highly curated poly(A)-positive 3’ ends as a ground truth. These 3’ ends were derived from a FLAM-seq-based dataset (Legnini et al. 2019; Alfonso-Gonzalez et al. 2023), where transcript ends were defined by the presence of non-templated poly(A) as no oligo-dT priming was involved in the library preparation. Trained on sequence features from this dataset, the classifier was applied to the 3’ ends of all the CFC-seq reads and to the GENCODE transcript models, resulting a score for likelihood of each 3’ end to derive from a canonical PolII termination event. This poly(A) score revealed high performance with AUC ~ 93% from the THP-1 non-PAT and PATspecific 3’ ends (Ext_Fig. 1h). Thresholds for defining poly(A)-positive and -negative were extracted from the ROC curve with 95% confidence. These read-base analyses including the presence of PAS, poly(A) score and identifier were summarised in Table S1 and were transferred to the 3’ ends of the final transcript models.

sec.title: CFC-seq identifies genuine TSS to indicate primary transcription
sec.p: A key feature for defining genuine TSSs is the presence of an unencoded G immediately upstream of the 5’ end of the mapped read (Cumbie et al. 2015), a characteristic seen in approximately 80% of qualified CFC-seq reads (Ext_Fig. 2a & 3h). Combining the CFC-seq libraries of the two differentiation time courses, 159,116 genuine TSS clusters were identified by SCAFE (Moody et al. 2022). These TSS clusters were extended and merged into 73,328 transcribed CREs (tCREs) with a median length of 501 bp (Fig. 2a). Integrating their genomic locations with the SCREEN cCREs (The ENCODE Project Consortium et al. 2020) revealed 30,695 promoter-like and 32,416 enhancer-like tCREs. Heatmap showing their expression level highlighted the cell-type specific nature of the enhancer-like tRCEs. (Fig. 2b). Proximal TSS clusters within 75 nt were merged into extended 5’ end clusters (ex5_clusters) to define 5’ end transcript classes in SALA and identify strand-specific summits (Fig. 2a). Next, the tCREs observed from the Neuron series were intersected with single-cell ATAC-seq peaks derived from the same samples, showing that majority of tCREs overlap with accessible chromatin regions (Fig. 2c). From the tCREs without cCRE support (unclassed), ~29% of them are proximal to the starting sites of GENCODE transcript models (Ext_Fig. 2b). Apart from these annotated tCREs, around 36% of ATAC-supported unclassed tCREs are specific to NSC, which was not an annotated cell-type in the SCREEN. To further explore the content of the unclassed tCREs, these tCREs were intersected with the ChromHMM chromatin states of the Neuron series (Yip et al. 2024). About 52% of non-ATAC unclassed tCRE intersected with the ChromHMM promoter or enhancer regions (Ext_Fig. 2c). The remaining 48% show a higher incidence of tCRE summits originating from exons (n = 104) and 3’ UTRs (n = 246) of annotated genes, regions previously reported as capped 3’ UTR-derived RNAs (Haberman et al. 2023). The tCREs with and without GENCODE, cCRE or ATAC support are summarised in Table S2. Notably, transcript models originating from unclassified tCREs were included in the final transcriptome, but labeled as non-independent transcripts when lacking ATAC support for open chromatin. Overall, our approach simultaneously identified TSS clusters and full-length long-read molecules, facilitating the precise definition of independent transcription and linking transcript models to well-defined tCREs and promoter types.

The tCRE’s summit represents the major TSS of a tCRE. They were extracted and extended in a strand-specific manner to intersect with various promoter features. The genomic location of these tCREs resemble features of promoter, including high GC content and conserved sequence while the summits were consistent with the feature of transcription start sites revealed by the position of TATA box and initiator (Ext_Fig. 2d). Enhancer-like tCREs were shown to have all these properties at lower but comparable levels as the promoter-like tCREs, suggesting the identified enhancer-like tCREs are capable to initiate transcription. It is noted that enhancer-like tCREs show enrichment of GC content and CpG island (CGI) downstream of the summit (Ext_Fig. 2d). As CGI is more accessible by various regulatory factors, this distribution implies that CGIs may play a crucial role in enhancing the activity of target promoters rather than driving the transcription of the eRNAs. Coincidently, CGIs proximal to poised enhancers were found to amplify enhancer activity towards CGI promoters in mouse embryonic stem cells (Pachano et al. 2021). To this end, we subset the enhancers which overlap with significant H3K27me3 repressive histone mark identified from our iPSC CUT&Tag data. This group of enhancers represent “transcribed poised enhancers”. It is noted that >50% of these poised enhancers produce eRNAs in the iPSC while others are produced from NSC, Neuron or THP-1 (Fig. 2d). Poised or bivalent (overlap with both H3K27ac and H3K27me3) enhancers were found significantly enriched with the presence of upstream CGI (uCGI) and downstream CGI (dCGI) (Fig. 2e). On the contrary, TATA box enhancers were depleted from H3K27me3 but enriched with active state and the state devoid of both H3K27ac and H3K27me3 (Fig. 2e).

sec.title: Bidirectional enhancers are more conserved, due to CpG islands
sec.p: Bidirectional transcription was reported as a feature of enhancers (Andersson et al. 2014). Using the 5’ end signal from the qualified reads (Ext_Fig. 3a, Methods), we have identified 12,984 2D enhancerlike tCREs and 9,635 2D promoter-like tCREs (Fig. 2d). Super enhancer (SE) represents clusters of active CREs in genomic proximity that control cell identity (Hnisz et al. 2013). Using ROSE (Lovén et al. 2013), we identified 1932, 1278 and 1790 SE regions from iPSC, NSC and Neuron respectively (Ext_Fig. 3b), with median SE sizes from 34 to 59 kb (Ext_Fig. 3c). Enhancer-like tCREs were then classified as SE or typical enhancer (TE) in each of the three cell-types (Fig. 2d). We then explored if directionality and SE clustering showed differences in CRE conservation. Using the sequence 500 bp upstream the tCRE summit, 2D tCREs are significantly more conserved than 1D tCREs (Fig. 2e & Ext_Fig. 3d). Super enhancer was reported as more conserved over other enhancers (Khan et al. 2018) in a context of chromatin state-defined enhancers. In our study of “transcribed” enhancers, TE is comparably conserved as SE (Fig. 2e & Ext_Fig. 3e). We reasoned that the presence of uCGI/dCGI contributed to the conservation observed in the 2D tCRE and classified the tCRE for the enrichment of CGI and for containing a TATA box (Methods). For both enhancer and promoter, 2D tCREs are enriched with CGI while 1D tCREs are enriched with TATA box (Ext_Fig. 3f). By comparing the tCREs with or without CGI and TATA box, both 1D and 2D enhancers carrying CGI are significantly more conserved (Ext_Fig. 3g). These results indicated that presence of the CGI in the enhancers contributed to the sequence conservation. It is noted that some distal tCREs are strand-independent and the strand with greater summit count was chosen for the analyses. To obtain the signal from both strands and synchronise the analyses with the transcript models, above analyses were also performed on the ex5_clusters (n = 60351) that linked to the finalised transcript models. These results are consistent with the results derived from the tCREs (Supplementary Fig. S1 & Table S2).

sec.title: CFC-seq identifies repetitive element-enriched tCREs
sec.p: Employing the same CAP-trapping molecular protocol, identification of tCRE is highly comparable between CFC-seq and CAGE. These include the percentage of reads with un-encoded G (Ext_Fig. 3h) and the position of single-nucleotide CTSS (Ext_Fig. 3i). Specific to the CFC-seq, a portion of reads (~30%) were revealed with a relatively long 5’ region unaligned to the genome. These reads were considered as non-qualified for TSS clusters identification with a cutoff of unaligned length > 3 nt. The transcript models generated by them independently will be filtered in the latter steps if the 5’ end locates outside the defines ex5_cluster. Further, pool identification of tCREs with both CFC-seq and CAGE (Ext_Fig. 2a) revealed the similar tCRE content and quantification (Ext_Fig. 3j-k).

Since long-read sequencing is suited for more accurately distinguishing genomic location of the repetitive elements (Maeng et al. 2023), we compared the identification rate of TSS clusters among CFC-seq, paired-end and single-end CAGE. CFC-seq shows a better performance in identifying TSSs covered by repeat sequence, compared to CAGE at different MAPQ thresholds (Fig. 2h). Further analysis revealed that these repetitive element-enriched TSSs specifically identified by CFC-seq are evolutionarily younger (Fig. 2i), concurring with a recent publication (Lee et al. 2023). With the longer read length from the CFC-seq, TSSs covered by repetitive elements are unambiguously and reliably annotated. From the 73,328 tCREs, 64.7% overlapped with any of the highlighted 7 families of repetitive elements (Ext_Fig. 3l). Among these tCREs, DNA transposons, LINEs, SINEs and LTRs are enriched in enhancer-like tCREs (Ext_Fig. 3m). From the enhancer-like tCREs, LINEs and LTRs are enriched in 1D-enhancers. Conversely, short tandem repeats (STRs) showed enrichment in promoter-like CREs, with CGG/CCG being the most notable motif.

sec.title: SALA identified 39,425 novel genes from CFC-seq
sec.p: We subjected approximately 236 million mapped alignments to TranscriptClean (Wyman and Mortazavi 2019) to correct splice junctions. These corrected alignments were then processed with SALA to collapse the reads into transcript models (Fig. 3a; Methods). The SALA raw output excluded the transcript models affected by internal priming and un-detected transcripts from the reference (GENCODE v39) and included a temporary assignment of gene annotation. To establish a confident assembly, we kept only the transcript models with their starting sites linked to the confident ex5_clusters supported by SCAFE and applied a tailored filter (Ext_Fig. 4x, Methods) Notably, we did not directly require reproducibility from the transcript models but rely on the reproducibility of the TSS clusters (SCAFE regression probability ≥ 0.5). The finalised transcript and gene models were shown in Table S3. Next, we classified the transcript models for their promoter type originated from the SCREEN cCRE-classed tCRE, according to their linked TSS clusters. Promoter types at the gene level were assigned according to the transcript ratio (Methods). From this finalised assembly with 194,138 transcript models, 47,984 known fulllength transcripts (ENST) were detected with the identification of 146,154 novel transcripts (Fig. 3b). The transcript models were tested for their coding potential by CPAT (Wang et al. 2013). Over 80% of the group “transcripts from novel genes” were determined as non-coding, compared to around 25% for the ENST (Fig. 3c). The novel transcript models of this final dataset are all supported by SCAFE (Ext_Fig. 4a) while the 3’ ends were annotated by cluster confidence (≥ 5 counts or covering GENCODE 3’ end) and poly(A) possibility (presence of PAS or poly(A) prediction) (Ext_Fig. 4b).

To benchmark SALA’s performance, the alignments were also processed with TALON (Wyman et al. 2019) and IsoQuant (Prjibelski et al. 2023). Transcript models affected by putative internal priming were filtered with the same condition from each assembly. In addition to the SALA final transcript models, we prepared the raw (Table S4) and read-filtered (Table S5) transcript models for this comparison (Ext_Fig. 4c). These tools are comparable in terms of detection of known transcript models (ENST) (Ext_Fig. 4d), except IsoQuant excluded models partially matched to ENST. SALA was developed to identify completely and partially matched ENST that are distinguishable. The transcript models identified using these different tools with different conditions were classified universally by SQANTI3 (Pardo-Palacios et al. 2024). SALA read-filtered models showed similar percentage of transcript type classification with TALON read-filtered models, where both adopted similar assembling algorithm including the use the TranscriptClean to pre-adjust the alignments (Ext_Fig. 4e). The SALA final transcriptomes showed a greater proportion of “intergenic” and “antisense” transcript classes, revealing our strategy in identifying novel confident ncRNAs. Transcripts from novel genes were observed from the raw output of TALON and the raw transcriptome of SALA, while many of them were maintained by SALA final transcriptome for genuine TSS support. (Ext_Fig. 4f). While SALA showed the highest discovery rate of transcripts from novel genes, a comparable rate of 5’ end support by ATAC open-chromatin regions and SCREEN cCRE epigenetic regions was observed across all the tools (Ext_Fig. 4g). When compared with the CFC-seq derived SCAFE TSS clusters, only a small fraction of TALON transcript models was supported. This revealed a different strategy in deciding the model 5’ ends where TALON prioritised reference 5’ ends but SALA opted to use data-driven 5’ ends obtained from the CAP-trap protocol. In summary, SALA outperformed the other tools in obtaining transcript models of novel genes, which are predominantly ncRNAs. This information is useful for the in-depth characterization of regulatory regions of the genome.

sec.title: About 93% of novel genes were classified as ncRNAs
sec.p: From the group “transcripts from novel genes”, transcript models with CPAT score < 0.364 were classed as non-coding (Wang et al. 2013). Novel genes containing > 50% complete reads assigned to non-coding transcripts were classed as non-coding genes. Non-coding genes with median read lengths of all non-coding transcripts ≥ 200 bp were classed as lncRNAs. This resulted in 35,848 novel lncRNA genes and 1,062 short_ncRNA genes (Ext_Fig. 4h). Only non-coding transcripts from the non-coding genes were considered as ncRNAs in the downstream analyses. Additionally, 2,948 novel lncRNA transcripts were identified from the “New isoform of GENCODE model”. In summary, we have identified 115,275 novel ncRNA transcripts and detected 6559 known lncRNA transcripts (Ext_Fig. 4i). These 121,834 ncRNA transcripts were then further subclassed according to the genomic location of GENCODE coding-genes and pseudogenes (Fig. 3d, Methods) for the downstream analyses. From the 39,425 novel genes, 35,848, 1,062 and 2,515 genes were defined as lncRNA, short_ncRNA and potentially coding RNA respectively. The ncRNA genes were subclassed according to the transcripts (Methods).

sec.title: CFC-seq identified 22,506 novel genes out of multiple databases
sec.p: In order to linked the novel genes identified from CFC-seq with other key databases, we compared the novel transcript models with Refseq, the latest version (v45) of GENCODE, and two lncRNA resources: FANTOM CAT (Hon et al. 2017) and LncBook (Li et al. 2023). At the transcript level, about 6% of the novel transcript models were annotated by at least one of these databases, with 4.4% contributed from the FANTOM CAT (Ext_Fig. 5a). To identify transcript models from these 4 databases belonging to the CFC-seq novel genes, transcript models sharing any features (5’ end clusters, 3’ end clusters and any splicing junction) or having 10% exon overlap with the CFC-seq models were grouped as the same genes. At the gene level, 57% of our novel genes are unannotated from any of the 4 databases (Ext_Fig. 5b). Although FANTOM CAT database contains less ncRNAs than LncBook (Ext_Fig. 5c), it showed the highest rate of overlap with CFC-seq. This is due to the requirement of TSS in identifying ncRNAs for both FANTOM CAT and CFC-seq. These novel genes observed from CFC-seq are relatively more cell-type specific and lowly expressed (Ext_Fig. 5d). The linked transcript ID from these 4 databases to the novel transcript and genes in this study are listed in Table S6.

Next, we quantified the short-read RNA-seq of the Neuron series by kallisto (Bray et al. 2016), using the final transcript models plus all the GENCODE models (v39) as reference. Over 80% of the novel transcript models and over 97% novel gene models were detected from the short-read RNA-seq data (Ext_Fig. 5e), suggesting most of the novel models can be observed from an independent sequencing technique. The undetected novel models revealed with similar proportion of ncRNA subclass as the detected ones (Ext_Fig. 5f) while they are expressed lower than the detected ones.

sec.title: Enhancer transcribes ncRNA with a greater length than previously reported
sec.p: The ex5_clusters (genuine TSS cluster with extension) were divided into 4 groups according to the promoter types, which were inherited from the tCRE as promoter-like, enhancer-like, CTCF-alone with ATAC support and unclassed with ATAC support. Additionally, ex5_clusters producing GENCODE coding genes alone were grouped as a control. These resulted in 9,749 ex5_clusters with mRNA outputs, 17,045 promoter-like ex5_clusters with ncRNA outputs (p_ncRNA), 28,718 enhancer-like ex5_clusters with ncRNA (e_ncRNA), 194 ATAC-supported CTCF-alone ex5_clusters with ncRNA (CTCF_ncRNA) and 4,645 ATAC-supported unclassed ex5_clusters with ncRNA (other_ncRNA).

We first investigated the transcript features from the RNAs grouped by their ex5_clusters. The median lengths of mRNAs, p_ncRNAs, e_ncRNAs and other_ncRNAs, were 2120 nt, 617 nt, 659 nt and 722 nt respectively (Fig. 4a & Ext_Fig. 6a). Here, the observed length of e_ncRNA with 659 nt is longer than previously reported, with a range of 346 - 449 nt (Andersson et al. 2014; Hou and Kraus 2022). Definition of e_ncRNA from this study is the ncRNAs derived from enhancers which are identified from genuine TSS integrated with enhancer-like chromatin signals (SCREEN). Commonly used representation of enhancers or CREs included ATAC-seq derived accessible CREs distal from GENCODE transcripts (Zhang et al. 2021), 5’ end sequencing protocol derived tCREs distal from GENCODE transcripts (Moody et al. 2023), distal bi-directionally transcribed RNAs (Andersson et al. 2014) and chromatin state-defined CREs (Khan et al. 2018). We grouped the ex5_clusters according to these criteria and measured the length of ncRNA products. This resulted in the median lengths between 652-704 nt (Ext_Fig. 4b), while these subgroups contain trace amounts of other_ncRNA and p_ncRNA (Ext_Fig. 4c). With the same groupings, 22% e_ncRNAs were found to be spliced (Fig. 4b) compared to 5% in a previous study (Andersson et al. 2014). From the other enhancer definitions, 19-26% of eRNA show splicing activity (Ext_Fig. 4d). Overall, CFC-seq revealed eRNA with a longer transcript length and more frequent splicing activity than previously observed.

sec.title: Downstream CpG islands and TATA box correlate with eRNA length and splicing
sec.p: As the promoter structure was found to affect RNA splicing (Cramer et al. 1997; Pandya-Jones 2011), which affect RNA length (described in next section), we investigated if the genomic properties of enhancer correlate with RNA length and splicing activity. These properties include bidirectionality, being within the SE clusters, sequence conservation, and presence of TATA box, uCGI and dCGI, of the ex5_clusters. Among them, presence of uCGI and dCGI correlated with shorter eRNA significantly while presence of TATA box and more conserved sequence correlated with longer eRNA (Fig. 4c). While bidirectionality and being within SE clusters showed subtle effect on the length of e_ncRNAs, they significantly correlated with less splicing events (Fig. 4d). Additionally, uCGI and dCGI correlated with less splicing events while TATA box correlated with more splicing events (Fig. 4d). Since the regulatory elements (TATA box, uCGI and dCGI) sometimes coexist in an enhancer (Ext_Fig. 3f) and may affect each other, ex5_clusters with only one of these regulatory elements were grouped and compared. Analyses of transcript length and splicing event verified the role of dCGI for shorter length and less splicing events and TATA box for longer length and higher splicing activity (Fig. 4e-f). These analyses were also performed on the p_ncRNAs with less obvious enrichment except for the presence of dCGI showing shorter ncRNAs (Ext_Fig. 6e-h). To better illustrate the genomic properties of dCGI and TATA box enhancer, we explored their enrichment against the other genomic properties from the ex5_cluster. Both 2D- and super-enhancer showed depletion of TATA box but subtle enrichment of dCGI (Fig. 4g), suggesting the lack of TATA box maybe a factor of the lower splicing activity in 2D- and super-enhancer. Further, ubiquitous enhancers (≥ 1 read from all 5 cell types) are enriched with uCGI/dCGI and depleted with TATA box, consistent to our previous study (Carninci et al. 2006). Overall, enhancer structure (dCGI and TATA box) was found to affect RNA splicing and length while these effects extended to enhancer types (bidirectionality and SE clustering) due to their depletion of TATA box.

sec.title: Presence of poly(A) tail and splicing enriched with longer ncRNA
sec.p: It is noted that dCGI directly affect sequence conservation downstream of the TSS (Fig. 4g) and the sequence composition of the transcript body. To identify the factors affecting the transcription from the transcript body, the 4 classes of RNA (mRNA, p_ncRNA, e_ncRNA and other_ncRNA) were grouped at the transcript model level. Protein-coding mRNAs (n = 28,230) were defined as any complete and known transcripts annotated as coding genes by GENCODE. Non-coding RNAs (n = 121,834) were noncoding transcript models derived from non-coding genes annotated in this study or by GENCODE (Ext_Fig. 4i). The presence of poly(A) tail for each transcript model was determined by having the poly(A) prediction positive or the presence of PAS from 5 to 50 nt upstream of the 3’ end. The occurrence of splicing and poly(A) correlated with longer eRNA (Fig. 4h). These transcripts were grouped into the ex5_clusters considering the weighted frequency of transcript models that are poly(A) positive. Dividing the ex5_clusters with the regulatory elements, the ncRNA content derived from dCGI enhancer constituted significantly less poly(A) RNA compared to that of TATA box enhancer (Fig. 4i). This result is specific to enhancer and was not observed from p_ncRNA.

sec.title: Chromatin-bound and exosome sensitivity
sec.p: As eRNA degrades rapidly in general, we adopted CFC-seq on the chromatin-bound fraction of iPSCs (Ext_Fig. 1a) in order to increase eRNA recovery and assess which RNAs that are specifically enriched from this fraction. We applied SALA on the chromatin-bound iPSC using the finalised transcriptome with all the GENCODE transcript models as the reference, where newly identified transcript models were labelled independently from the main dataset (Table S7). This dataset revealed an addition of 10,857 ncRNA genes while 6,476 of them are derived from enhancer (Ext_Fig. 6i). Using exosome knockdown RNA-seq data from another line of iPSC (Yip et al. 2022), chromatin-bound eRNAs were found to be more exosome-sensitive (Ext_Fig. 6j). Further, the genes were grouped by ex5_clusters where one gene was allowed to have multiple ex5_clusters but only those ex5_clusters with one gene were kept. The exosome sensitivity was tested against different enhancer features from the ex5_clusters. Enhancers with uCGI, dCGI, 2D, being clustered as SE and ubiquitously active generate eRNAs that are significantly more sensitive to exosome degradation, while TATA box enhancer generates eRNAs that are significantly less sensitive (Fig. 4j). These results agree with our discoveries on the splicing, transcript length, and the presence of ploy(A) tail between CGI and TATA box enhancers. Overall, we grouped the ex5_clusters according to the enhancer structure and observed that dCGI enhancers transcribed shorter RNA with high sensitivity to exosome degradation while TATA box enhancers are more frequently spliced, polyadenylated, longer and more stable.

sec.title: Non-coding RNA showed low splicing efficiency
sec.p: To extend our observation of ncRNA splicing activity, we investigate the confidence, recurrence and efficiency of the splicing junctions (SJs). The SJs observed from our models were annotated using junctions confidently observed from our short-read sequencing (Methods), junctions reported by Intropolis (Nellore et al. 2016) and GENCODE (v39) junctions (Ext_Fig. 7a). Considering the SJs from the final transcriptome, majority of them are annotated by GENCODE while the others are largely supported by Intropolis and short-read SJs (Fig. 5a), leaving 11.8% SJs non-supported. For these remaining novel SJs, their counts and base-calling quality scores nearby the junctions (± 3nt) were used as an indicator of technical confidence. With the summarised base-calling score >=10 and counts >=3, 8.9% (both canonical and non-canonical) of the novel SJs was considered confident (Ext_Fig. 7b). Overall, 89.3% SJs observed from the final transcriptome were either supported by external databases or passing the quality score. The quality of these SJs were incorporated to the transcript models that were grouped as mRNA, p_ncRNA, e_ncRNA and other_ncRNA as described above. ~90% of the spliced ncRNAs have all of their SJs considered as confident (Ext_Fig. 7c). In addition, most of SJs observed from the p_ncRNA and e_ncRNA are canonical (Ext_Fig. 7d), echoing the findings of a previous study (Gil and Ulitsky 2018). Overall, we showed that SJs identified by CFC-seq and SALA are largely supported by external datasets while SJs from ncRNAs are comparable to SJs from mRNA.

Although the SJ motif class from ncRNAs are comparable to that of mRNA, not all the junction splices at the same efficiency (Melé et al. 2017). To address this, we calculated the splicing efficiency of all the junctions and summarised the normalised splicing efficiency at the gene level (Fig. 5b). Across several different cutoffs of occurrence as the SJ inclusion criteria, splicing efficiency of ncRNAs is significantly lower than mRNAs, where p_ncRNAs showed a significantly lower efficiency compared to the e_ncRNAs (Fig. 5c). Since the accuracy of this splicing efficiency highly depends on the expression level, splicing efficiency of those lowly expressed RNAs was not included. In order to improve the coverage of the analysis, spliceAI (de Sainte Agathe et al. 2023) was incorporated as a sequence-base estimation of splicing probability for all the SJs observed. The splicing efficiencies for donor site, acceptor site and junction are correlated with the spliceAI score (Ext_Fig. 7e). The normalised spliceAI score at the gene level resulted with the same observation of less effective splicing event from the ncRNAs (Ext_Fig. 7f).

The gene-based splicing efficiency was transferred to the ex5_cluster groups where one gene might assign to multiple ex5_clusters but only the clusters with one gene were kept (Methods). After dividing the ex5_clusters with promoter structures, splicing efficiency of RNA derived from dCGI and uCGI enhancers were found significantly lower than that of TATA box enhancers (Fig. 5d). This phenomenon was consistent across e_ncRNA and p_ncRNA (Fig. 5e). Since enhancers were shown to enrich with TATA box while promoters were enriched with CGI (Ext_Fig. 3f), these promoter structures contributed to the observation of the greater splicing efficiency of e_ncRNA than p_ncRNA in Figure 5c. Splicing efficiency for each gene model is listed (Table S8).

sec.title: The 3’ end cleavage site of eRNA shows depletion of secondary structure
sec.p: From the CFC-seq data, SALA has successfully identified 6,683 poly(A) and 2,239 non-poly(A) 3’ ends from e_ncRNAs having at least 3 counts at the 3’ ends. The 3’end processing of eRNA is partially resolved (Lai et al. 2015) (Welsh and Gardini 2023), where the integrator complex was identified to cleave the eRNA 3’ end. However, the cleavage position or the RNA motif at the cleavage site is unknown. From the recursive non-poly(A) 3’ end of ncRNA, we observed a very different sequence composition from the ones with poly(A) (Fig. 5f). In addition to the absence of PAS motif, a relatively high content of cysteine was observed upstream the 3’ end. As the RNA secondary structure was reported to hinder 3’ end cleavage in the canonical poly(A) pathway (Klasens 1998), we measure the secondary structure score by RNAfold (Lorenz et al. 2011) surrounding the 3’ ends of poly(A) and non-poly(A) eRNAs. Similar to the 3’end of poly(A) eRNA, we observed a valley of secondary structure score at the 3’ end of non-poly(A) eRNA, suggesting this as a preferred feature of cleavage site (Fig. 5g). Further, the sequence of recursive non-ploy(A) surrounding the 3’ end was subjected to motif search. A C-rich motif and a CA dinucleotide repeat were identified directly upstream and downstream of the 3’ end.

sec.title: Expansion of non-coding sequence for functional implication
sec.p: Many annotated eQTL and GWAS SNPs are located outside the protein coding genes and their promoters. These SNPs may affect the nearby CREs or ncRNAs in regulating the protein coding genes. The eQTL and GWAS data were obtained from eQTL Catalogue (Kerimov et al. 2020) and CAUSALdb (Wang et al. 2019) respectively. To investigate if the novel transcript models identified in this study harbour some of these SNPs, they were intersected against GENCODE v39 and our novel models. The exons specific to the novel models revealed 21% and 31% increase of coverage of eQTL and GWAS SNPs respectively compared to the GENCODE models (Fig. 6a), while the majority of the increase detected from the transcript from novel genes (Fig. 6b). To explore the effect of these SNPs on the SJs of the transcript model, the donor and acceptor sites were tested against these SNPs in spliceAI. The novel transcript models contributed to 4.9-17% increase of splicing interference mediated by eQTL and GWAS SNPs. In Figure 6b, only those SNPs reduce the splicing potential were counted while the full list with a cutoff of delta score at 0.5 was shown in Table S9. Overall, the novel transcript models identified from this study increase the coverage of annotated eQTL and GWAS SNPs by at least 20% while the splicing interference represents one of the functional mechanisms of these SNPs.

sec.title: CGI enhancers show greater chromatin connectivity
sec.p: Due to the different properties of ncRNAs and enhancers derived from dCGI and TATA box, we extracted the number of SNPs from different enhancer structure (Ext_Fig. 8a). Enhancer with only dCGI was found to have the highest hit rate of eQTL SNPs against background SNPs, with about 2-fold as the TATA box enhancer (Fig. 6c). The eQTL results were similar in exons, where the relatively short eRNAs overlap more with the dCGI that regulates enhancer activity. This result may imply a more established enhancer function from the dCGI enhancer. To explore the enhancer function contributed by different enhancer structures, the interaction between these enhancers and protein-coding gene promoters was predicted by Hi-C performed on the Neuron series. Using the interaction from all 3 cell types, the number of coding gene promoters in contact with dCGI and uCGI enhancers were found significantly greater than that of TATA box enhancer (Fig. 6d). This result is consistent when the analysis performed at each cell type separately (Ext_Fig. 8b). This finding echoed the observation from the eQTL SNPs and suggested a broader enhancer role of uCGI/dCGI enhancer than TATA box enhancer. This result also concurs with a previous study that CGI enhancers showed higher Hi-C contacts than classical enhancers, where enhancers were epigenetically defined (Bell and Vertino 2017). Further, chromatin accessibility and GC content of the Hi-C contact regions revealed that regions with uCGI/dCGI enhancer were more accessible with higher GC content while both were correlated with contact frequency (Ext_Fig. 8c-d). As expected, SE was shown with higher chromatin connectivity (Ext_Fig. 8e). This is consistent with our results showing that uCGI/dCGI is enriched with SE (Fig. 4g). In addition, uCGI/dCGI enhancers were shown to interact with CGI promoters more frequently (Ext_Fig. 8f), which is consistent to a previous study (Pachano et al. 2021).

sec.title: TATA box derived eRNAs enriched with LTRs
sec.p: Given the significant contribution of transposable elements to the human genome, and the enrichment of enhancer-like tCREs with SINEs, LINEs and LTRs (Ext_Fig. 3m), we reasoned that TATA box-derived eRNAs might be influenced by these transposable elements. We intersected repetitive elements with both the ex5_clusters and transcript models (merged exons) and categorized them as dCGI, uCGI, TATA, and Null. Analysis of both ex5_clusters and transcript models revealed that LTRs were specifically enriched in TATA box enhancers and depleted from uCGI/dCGI enhancers (Fig. 6e). This enrichment pattern was consistent across the p_ncRNA, CTCF_ncRNA, and other_ncRNA groups (Ext_Fig. 8g). Notably, LTR elements were highly enriched in the other_ncRNA category (unclassified by SCREEN promoter-typing) with TATA box enhancers accounting for 57% (n = 342), suggesting that these elements are a prominent transcription source within this group (Ext_Fig. 8g). With a threshold of at least 200 nt overlap, approximately 27% (n = 551) of RNAs transcribed from TATA box enhancers were found to originate from LTRs (Fig. 6f). Within the LTR families, ERV1 emerged as the predominant contributor to TATA box eRNAs (Ext_Fig. 8h). Quantification of ex5_clusters using the RLE-normalised TSS count revealed the higher cell-type specificity of the TATA box enhancers, but TATA box enhancers were observed across different cell types (Ext_Fig. 8g). Specifically, the LTR subgroup of TATA box enhancers showed pronounced enrichment in iPSCs and NSCs (Fig. 6g).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study introduced a novel long-read RNA-sequencing protocol accompanied with the SALA assembler. We demonstrated the annotation of both TSS and full-length transcript model from the same RNA molecule effectively identified novel genes with confident TSS. The incorporation of PAT was shown to successfully include non-poly(A) RNA and almost double the number of ncRNA reads.

Transcription from enhancers and the presence of eRNAs in the human genome are well-established. However, their low abundance hinders transcript model construction using short-read RNA-seq. Although CFC-seq aids in annotating eRNAs with splicing junctions and relatively precise transcript end sites, creating reliable transcript models with limited sequencing depth remains challenging. Since the majority of the eRNAs lacks a canonical polyadenylation signal (Ext_Fig. 4c), the concept of typical complete mRNA model with both a defined TSS and poly(A) tail, often does not apply to eRNAs. The use of 3’ end clusters to observe recursive transcript end sites provided an additional layer of confidence, albeit hindered by the low expression level of eRNAs. From the analyses showing higher content of “nascent” RNA from the chromatin fraction also suggested that most eRNAs are “incomplete” in nature. Importantly, the eRNAs identified in this study were derived from total RNA under standard cell culture conditions, likely representing the natural, full-length format of these transcripts.

Identification of enhancers in a cell type is generally based on chromatin state and transcriptional activity with transcribed enhancers typically being more active (Andersson et al. 2014). Enhancers are known to exhibit high GC content and are frequently located near orphan CGIs though transcribed enhancers tend to be depleted of CGIs and simple repeats. Because TATA box identification depends on the reference location of the TSS, TATA box-associated enhancers were reliably observed only when transcription was detected. The precise identification of eRNA TSSs also allowed us to observe that enhancer CGIs are often positioned downstream of the TSS, distinguishing them from promoters. By integrating transcriptional activity and chromatin state, our study systematically elucidates these enhancer structures and characterizes the RNA produced from them. From the set of transcribed enhancers, we identified both CGI-specific and TATA box-specific enhancers. TATA box enhancers were observed to produce longer, more stable, and more extensively spliced and polyadenylated eRNAs, though they were less connected compared to CGI enhancers (Fig. 6h). CGI enhancers appeared more ubiquitous across cell types, whereas TATA box enhancers were more cell-type-specific, suggesting that ubiquitous enhancers are more connected in enhancer networks. Interestingly, CGI enhancers were enriched with H3K27me3 marks, indicating poised or bivalent states, which implies that they may represent a more readily activated enhancer class. In contrast, TATA box enhancers were characterized as either active or lacking both H3K27Ac and H3K27me3 marks, suggesting that their activation may involve a complex mechanism—potentially initiated by pioneer factor binding followed by subsequent transcription factor regulation.

Based on TSSs identified by CFC-seq, eRNAs were observed to be transcribed upstream of CGIs (Ext_Fig. 2d), leading to the identification of a distinct group termed dCGI enhancers. This enhancer group produces the most exosome-sensitive and shortest eRNAs among the identified enhancer classes, indicating that dCGIs may limit eRNA activity while simultaneously enhancing regulatory potential. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon. Conversely, TATA box enhancers produce longer and more stable eRNAs, which enables them to explore the nuclear space in search of target sequences, potentially even in trans (Harrison and Bose 2022). A notable proportion of these eRNAs were originated from LTR retrotransposons, suggesting that their structural characteristics may contribute to this stability and nuclear exploratory function. LTR-derived RNAs have been shown to play roles in key biological processes such as pluripotency (Fort et al. 2014; Grow et al. 2015), neurogenesis (Wang et al. 2020) and neuronal diseases (Dawson et al. 2023).

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: We have performed size selection in the CFC-seq protocol to remove primers and adjust the overall read length distribution in each library, where the final libraries are similar to the initial cDNAs. Since the size selection may introduce bias to the size distribution of different RNA types, our conclusion on RNA length is limited by this protocol. The CFC-seq libraries from the THP-1 were mainly used as protocol development for the effect of poly(A)-tailing. We have included them in building transcript models but avoid comparing them with the Neuron series samples.

Although dCGI, uCGI and TATA box enhancers were identified from this study, majority of the transcribed enhancers (Null, 81%) lacks these enhancer structures. Interesting, about 40% of these “Null” enhancer contains transposable elements (LTR, SINE and LINE) in the RNA body. Further investigation with alternative approaches is required to thoroughly understand the nature of these enhancers.

sec.title: Cell models
sec.p: Human iPS line i3N and THP-1 cells were used in this study. iPS line i3N is a gift from Dr. Michael Ward from NIH and derived from the WTC11 iPSC by introducing a doxycycline-inducible mNGN2 transgene at the AAVS1 site. THP-1 cells were subcloned by limited dilution and one clone (1-E9) was selected for relatively high sensitivity to PMA. The ability to differentiate relatively homogeneously in response to PMA was evidenced by expression of CD14 and CSF-1R quantified by ssCAGE.

sec.title: Cell culture
sec.p: The iPS cells were cultured in StemFit medium (Ajinomoto; Cat. No. RCAK02N) under feeder-free conditions at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 incubator. The cells were passaged when the culture was ~80% confluent. The cells were washed with DPBS and detached by incubating with Accutase (Sigma; Cat.No. A6964) at 37 °C for 10 min. After centrifuge, cells were resuspended in StemFit medium supplemented with 10 nM Rho-associated kinase (ROCK) inhibitor (Y-27632, Wako; Cat.No. 036-24023), and re-plated onto iMatrix-511 (Nippi; Cat.No. 892012)-coated plates. The following day, ROCK inhibitor was withdrawn by refreshing the StemFit medium. The medium was refreshed every other day. To prepare the cells for transcriptomic profiling, iPSC was plated at a density of 0.5 million cells per 10 cm-dish in 10mL of medium and collected by Accutase after four days. The THP-1_1-E9 cells were cultured in RPMI1640-GlutaMAX-I (Gibco) supplemented with 10% heat inactivated fetal bovine serum (Gibco), 100 U/mL penicillin, and 100 μg/mL streptomycin (Gibco). The cells were maintained in a humidified 37°C incubator with 5% CO2.

sec.title: Neural differentiation from iPSC to Neural stem cell (NSC)
sec.p: NSCs were generated by using the PSC Neural Induction Medium (NIM) (Gibco; Cat.No. A1647801). iPSCs were seeded onto an iMatrix511-coated 6-well plate at a density of 0.25 million per well in 2 mL of StemFit medium with 10 nM ROCK inhibitor. The following day, medium was replaced with 2.5 mL of NIM. NIM was refreshed every other day. On day 6 of neural induction, the NSCs (P0) were harvested by incubating with Accutase at 37 °C for 10 min and scraping. The cells were centrifuged at 300 x g for 5 min. The supernatant was aspirated and the cell pellet was resuspended with PSC Neural Expansion Medium (NEM) containing 10 nM ROCK inhibitor and seeded onto a iMatrix511-coated 10-cm dish at a density of one million cells per dish. The following day, the medium was refreshed to remove the ROCK inhibitor. Hereafter, NEM was replaced every other day. After 5 days, the expanded P1-NSCs were harvested and stocked with STEM-CELLBANKER (Nippon Zenyaku, Cat.No. CB045). To prepare the cells for transcriptomic profiling, the cryopreserved P1-NSCs were quickly thawed and cultured in NEM with 10 nM ROCK inhibitor on an iMatrix511-coated 10 cm-dish at a density of one million. After four days of culture, P2-NSCs were harvested by incubating with Accutase and scraping.

sec.title: Neural differentiation from NSC to cortical neuron
sec.p: The differentiation of cortical neurons from NSC using doxycycline-inducible mNGN2 was performed following the protocol developed in Dr. Peter Heutink’s Lab (DZNE), with modifications. Briefly, the cryopreserved P1-NSCs were passaged once. P2-NSCs were then replated onto 0.1mg/mL Poly-L-ornithine (Sigma, Cat.No. P3655)-coated 10cm-dish at a density of 5 × 106 cells per dish in the differentiation medium I (50% DMEM/F12 (Gibco, Cat.No. 10565018) and 50% Neurobasal Medium (Gibco; Cat.No. 21103049) as the base, supplemented with 0.5 × Non-Essential Amino Acids (NEAA, Gibco; Cat.No. 11140050), 0.5 × GlutaMAX (Gibco; Cat. No.35050-061), 0.5 × N-2 Supplement (Gibco; Cat. No. 17502048), 0.5X B-27 Supplement (Gibco; Cat. No. 17504-044), 2.5 μg/mL human Insulin (Sigma; Cat.No. 19278), 2 μM DAPT (Wako; Cat.No. 043-33581), 50 μM 2-Mercaptoethanol (Gibco; Cat. No. 21985023), 2 μg/mL doxycycline hydrochloride (Sigma; Cat.No. D-9891), 5 μg/mL Mouse Laminin, and 10 nM ROCK inhibitor). The following day, the same medium without ROCK inhibitor was used to replace medium. On day 3, the medium was changed to differentiation medium II (50% DMEM/F12 and 50% Neurobasal Medium as the base, supplemented with 0.5 × Non-Essential Amino Acids, 0.5 × GlutaMAX, 0.5 × N-2 Supplement, 0.5 × B-27 Supplement, 2.5 μg/mL human Insulin, 10 μM DAPT, 50 μM 2-Mercaptoethanol, 2 μg/mL doxycycline hydrochloride, 0.5 μg/mL Mouse Laminin, 10 ng/ml brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF, PeproTech; Cat.No. 450-02), 10 ng/ml glial cell-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF, PeproTech; Cat.No. 450-10), 10 ng/ml neurotrophin-3 (NT-3, PeproTech; Cat.No. 450-03), and 0.5 μg/ml laminin). On Day 6 onwards, the half of the medium was exchanged every 3 days without Doxycycline. On day 10, the differentiated neurons were harvested for the transcriptomic profiling. Briefly, the cells were incubated with dissociation buffer (50% Accutase, 50% DPBS, and ≥50 units papain (Worthington; Cat.No. LK003178)) at 37 °C for 20 min. Then, wash buffer (DMEM/F12 supplemented with GlutaMax, 10 nM ROCK inhibitor, and ≥ 500 Kunitz units DNaseI (Worthington, Cat.No. LK003172)) was added to the cells. The cells were collected, washed 3 times with 0.1% BSA in DPBS and centrifuged at 150 × g for 10 min to remove the dead cell debris.

sec.title: THP-1 differentiation
sec.p: 2 × 106 cells of THP-1_1-E9 were seeded in 10 cm dishes and treated with 30 ng/mL of PMA (Sigma) for 24 h and 96 h. As a negative control, THP-1_1-E9 cells were treated with 1/1,000 volume DMSO (Wako) in the culturing medium for 24 h and 96 h.

sec.title: RNA purification
sec.p: The harvested cells were subjected to RNA extraction and purification using the RNeasy Kit (Qiagen) with on-column DNaseI treatment according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The eluted RNA was quantified by the NanoDrop™ spectrophotometry platform (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The purified RNA samples were stored at -80 °C until they were used for the CFC-seq, ssCAGE and RNA-seq libraries construction.

sec.title: Cell fractionation
sec.p: Subcellular fractionation of i3N cells was performed similarly as previously described (Yip et al. 2022) with minor optimization. Briefly, approximately 10 million cells were used per fractionation experiment to obtain cytoplasmic (CYTO), soluble nucleoplasmic (SNUC) and chromatin (CHR) fractions. Cells detached by Accutase were washed with cold DPBS and lysed for 5 min using a cold lysis buffer containing 0.15% Igepal CA-630, 10 mM Tris pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl. The lysate was overlaid on a sucrose cushion containing 10 mM Tris pH 7.5, 150mM NaCl, 24% sucrose and centrifuged at 1000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C. The supernatant was removed and centrifuged at 14,000 x g for 1 min, after which the supernatant was taken as the CYTO fraction. The nuclear pellet was washed once in PBS containing 0.5 mM EDTA pH 8.0 and resuspended in a buffer containing 20 mM Tris pH 7.5, 50% glycerol, 75 mM NaCl, 0.5 mM EDTA. An equal volume of nuclear lysis buffer containing 10 mM Tris pH 7.5, 300 mM NaCl, 1M Urea, 1% Igepal CA-630, 7.5 mM MgCl2, 0.2 mM EDTA was added and incubated on ice for 5 min to lyse the nuclei. After centrifugation at 13,000 x g for 2 min at 4 °C, the supernatant was taken as the SNUC fraction and the pellet as the CHR fraction. The chromatin pellet was washed once in PBS containing 0.5 mM EDTA pH 8.0 and resuspended in the same buffer. RNA from each fraction was isolated using Trizol LS (Invitrogen), according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Prior to RNA extraction, chromatin which formed a tight precipitate was solubilized in Trizol LS by first passing through a 27-gauge needle, then treating with a dounce homogenizer. Extracted RNA was subjected to DNase I treatment followed by phenolchloroform extraction. Average RNA yields were 260 μg, 53 μg and 7 μg from the cytoplasmic, nucleoplasmic and chromatin fractions, respectively. The RNA from the chromatin fraction was subjected to CFC-seq cDNA library construction and sequenced by PromethION.

sec.title: CFC-seq experimental workflow
sec.p: For the total RNAs from the iPS, NSC and cortical neuron, 10 μg of RNAs were polyadenylated by incubating with E-coli poly(A) Polymerase (PAP) (NEB M0276) at 37°C for 15 min and purified with AMPure RNA Clean XP beads. For the total RNAs from the THP-1 series (DMSO 24h, DMSO 96h, PMA 24h and PMA 96h), 80 - 100 μg of RNAs were used both for PAP-treated and PAP-nontreated RNAs. For the iPS chromatin fraction RNAs, 5 μg of RNAs were polyadenylated. The RNA was reverse transcribed by Prime Script II Reverse Transcriptase (Takara Bio) at 42°C for 60 min with different poly-dT primer sets dependent on samples. For the PAP treated RNAs from iPS, NSC and cortical neuron, reverse transcription was done by poly-dT primer containing UMI: oligodT_16VN_UMI15 (GAGATGTCTCGTGGGCTCGGN15CTACGT16VN). The PAP-treated and PAP-nontreated RNAs from THP-1 series and PAP-treated chromatin RNAs were reverse transcribed with poly-dT primer containing ONT barcode: FL-ONT_dT16VN_NB01-NB08 (GAGATGTCTCGTGGGCTCGG[NB01-NB08]CTACGT16VN). The product was purified with RNAClean XP beads. Cap-trapping from the RNA/cDNA hybrids was performed as previously described (Takahashi et al. 2012). Then, RNA was digested with RNase H (Takara Bio) at 37°C for 30 min and the cDNA was purified with AMPureXP beads. Double stranded 5’ linker of N6 and GN5 (Table S10) were mixed at a ratio of 1:4 and ligated to the cDNA with Mighty Mix (Takara Bio) for overnight and the ligated cDNA was purified with AMPure XP beads. Shrimp Alkaline Phosphatase (Takara Bio) was used to remove phosphates at the ligated linker and purified with AMPureXP beads. The 5’ linker ligated cDNA was then subjected to second strand synthesis with KAPA HiFi mix (Roche) using a second strand primer with an UMI of 25 nucleotides (CTACACTCGTCGGCAGCGTCN25GTGGTATCAACGCAGAGTAC) at 95°C for 5 min, 55°C for 5 min and 72°C for 30 min. Exonuclease I (Takara Bio) was added to digest the excessed primers at 37°C for 30 min. After AMPureXP purification, the cDNA/DNA hybrids derived from the neuron series were amplified with PrimerSTAR GXL DNA polymerase (Takara Bio) for 10 cycles. The cDNA/DNA hybrids from the iPS chromatin-bound fraction were amplified with LongAmpR Taq DNA Polymerase (NEB, M0323) for 7 cycles. The amplified products were purified by AMPureXP. The amplified products from the Neuron series and the cDNA/DNA hybrids from the THP-1 series were subjected to library construction using the kit SQK-LSK110 (Oxford Nanopore Technologies) with the manufacturer’s instructions. The libraries were sequenced with R9.4.1 flow cell (FLO-MIN106) in MinION sequencer, by adding 50 fmol DNA per flow cell and sequenced for 72 hrs. For the chromatin-bound iPSC, purified product was subjected to library construction using kit V14 SQK-LSK114 (Oxford Nanopore Technologies). The libraries were sequenced in the R10.4.1 flow cell in the PromethION sequencer. For each sample replicate, the technical runs were pooled for further downstream analyses. All the oligo sequences are listed in Table S10.

sec.title: Single-strand CAGE (ssCAGE)
sec.p: After extracting and purifying the RNA from the 3 cell types, 15 μg of RNA was used from each sample for constructing a single-strand CAGE library (Takahashi et al. 2021). Libraries were subjected to 100-base pair-end sequencing using the Illumina NextSeq 1000/2000 P2 Reagents (200 Cycles) v3.

Reads were de-multiplexed and mapped in pair-end to the human genome (hg38) using STAR (Dobin et al. 2013). The median number of mapped CAGE paired reads obtained from each sample is about 60 million.

sec.title: Pre-processing of the long-read ONT data
sec.p: Basecalling was processed by Dorado v0.2.4 basecaller software provided by Oxford Nanopore Technologies to generate fastq files from FAST5 files using the model “dna_r9.4.1_e8_sup@v3.3”. Basecalled reads were filtered to ‘pass’ based on the average read Q-score > 10. For the rest of the downstream analysis, only Q-score pass reads were used. To prepare clean reads from the fastq files, adapter sequences were trimmed from the raw reads by primer chop (https://gitlab.com/mcfrith/primer-chop), requiring the presence of adaptor sequences from both ends. Primer-chop also orientates the strands based on the order of head and tail linkers appear in the read. Next, the poly(A) tails and cases where the poly-A tail is basecalled to random dinucleotide sequences of adenine and guanine were trimmed. We developed tail trimmer (v1.3) to scan with 20bp windows and trim the poly-A tail with maximum 5 As left.

The trimmed and orientated fastq reads were then mapped to the human genome, using the reference GRCh38_no_alt_analysis_set_GCA_000001405.15.fasta, along with accompanying GENCODE v39 annotation. For mapping, minimap2 v2.17-r974-dirty (Li 2018) was used. The raw alignments were then corrected using TranscriptClean v2.0.3 (Wyman and Mortazavi 2019) while a junction file containing confident junctions extracted from short-read RNA-seq on the Neuron series and the junctions from the GENCODE v39 were applied. An additional tag to the corrected alignments was then added using the TALON v5 (Wyman et al. 2019) talon_label_reads function which calculates the fraction of adenines in a 16-bp window within the genome immediately downstream of the last 3’-bp alignment of the read. This is required for running TALON but not other assemblers. [1]

GRCh38_no_alt_analysis_set_GCA_000001405.15.fasta --t 12 --tmpDir sample/tmp --deleteTmp --o sample

sec.title: Comparing 5’ end of different long-read protocols
sec.p: The fastq files of 5 different long-read protocols sequencing the same iPSC (WTC11) were downloaded from ENCODE LRGASP (CAP_trap_Pacbio: ENCSR309IKK; uncap_deplete_Pacbio: ENCSR507JOF; TOS_Ont: ENCSR539ZXJ; R2C2_Ont: ENCSR925UQZ; dRNA_Ont: ENCSR392BGY). These fastq files were mapped to hg38 by minimap2 as described above. The alignments of these libraries and our iPSC libraries were intersected with the exon of coding genes annotated by GENCODE v39, while alignments intersecting with ≥ 90% of any exon were included as mRNA in the analysis. The 5’ ends of these alignments (excluding chr M) were intersected with 3 external resources inferring promoter region. These resources included ENCODE SCREEN cCRE regions (either promoter or enhancer regions), the ATAC-peaks called from the single nucleus ATAC-seq we performed on the same iPSC, and the promoter regions (300 bp median) defined from FANTOM5 CAGE data. These regions are listed in supplementary table S11.

sec.title: Comparing 3’ ends from libraries with or without PAS motif
sec.p:
The 3’ ends from all the alignments were extracted. The DNA sequences ± 50 bp from the 3’ ends were obtained from the reference genome GRCh38_no_alt_analysis_set_GCA_000001405.15. The percentage of adenine downstream the 3’ end was calculated for potential internal priming. A percentage > 50% from 16 nucleotides downstream or > 75% from 8 nucleotides downstream is marked as internal priming. The 3’ ends of transcript models annotated by GENCODE v39 were protected. Position weight matrix was generated from PAS motifs annotated by GENCODE v39. We search for PAS motifs genome wide by scanMotifGenomeWide.pl of Homer v4.11 (Heinz et al. 2010) using a motif file generated from the GENCODE PAS motifs. Only the loci with score > 3 were used for the analysis. These PAS motifs include: “AATAAA”, “ATTAAA”, “AGTAAA”, “TATAAA”, “AATATA”, “ATTATA”, “TTTAAA”, “AAAAAA”, “AATTAA”, “AATAAG”, “AATACA”, “AAGAAA”, “ACTAAA”, “AATGAA”, “CATAAA”, “AATAAT”, “GATAAA”, “AATAGA”. The genomic locations of these PAS motifs were overlapped with the single-nucleotide locations 25 nt upstream of the 3’ ends by running bedtools closest. Presence of PAS motif 5 nt to 50 nt upstream the 3’ ends, according to the last nucleotide of the PAS motif, was annotated as PAS-positive. The RNA classes: mRNA, p_ncRNA and e_ncRNA were defined from SALA. The nucleotide composition surrounding the 3’ ends were plotted according to the reference genome. To subset the 3’ ends captured by PAT, 3’ ends from PAT THP-1 were subtracted by 3’ ends from the non-PAT THP1 libraries. [1]
scanMotifGenomeWide.pl PAS.motif hg38 -bed -keepAll -p 10 > output.bed[2]
bedtools closest -a all3n_up25.sort.bed.gz -b
GENCODE_polyA_signal.motif_rng.main.FASTA.6.bed.gz -s -D a | cut -f-6,10-| gzip > all3n_up25.PAS6.bed.gz

sec.title: Poly(A)-tail prediction
sec.p: In order to call bona fide 3’ ends for the transcripts detected by CFC-seq, we trained a random forest classifier on a curated database of 3’ ends identified by FLAM-seq and 3p-seq (Legnini et al. 2019; Alfonso-Gonzalez et al. 2023). Briefly, we collected all 3’ ends detected by CFC-seq and flagged those overlapping with the curated (hereon “reference”) dataset within a window of 10 nt. We then trained a random forest classifier using the ranger package (v. 0.16.0) in R 4.3.1, considering the 3’ ends found in the reference as true positives and defining a set of features to train the model on, including the presence, type and position of polyadenylation signals and the nucleotide composition of a 50 nt window upstream and downstream of each 3’ end. We then used the trained model to assign a probability score (“poly(A) score”) to each 3’ end in the CFC-seq dataset. We defined an upper threshold at which 95% of 3’ ends found in the reference and containing a polyadenylation signal were classified as true to define “poly(A)” 3’ ends (threshold > 0.34), and a lower threshold at which 95% of all 3’ ends were classified as true to flag “non-poly(A)” 3’ ends (threshold < 7.6e-5). We then performed motif enrichment analysis with the meme R package (v. 1.7.1) on six classes of 3’ ends, collapsed when closer to each other than 5 nt: 3’ ends for messenger, enhancer and promoter RNAs were filtered for being observed with more than 4, 2 and 2 unique reads respectively, and stratified for having a poly(A) score higher than 0.34 (threshold for “true” 3’ ends). In addition to the motif enrichment analysis, we also counted and ranked the occurrence of 6-mers in a window of 50 nt upstream and downstream of the 3’ ends for the same classes.

sec.title: Transcription start site identification by SCAFE
sec.p: The bam files containing all alignments mapped to the hg38 genome were used as the input for SCAFE v1.01 (Moody et al. 2022). Briefly, scafe.workflow.bk.bam_to_ctss extracted alignments with ≤ 3 nt softclip at the 5’ end and ≥ 30 matched nt, where ~70% reads passed. These qualified alignments (~165 million) were converted into CTSS, which were grouped into TSS clusters. According to the multiple properties of each TSS cluster (percentage of CTSS with unencoded G, corrected expression, read count, summit count and flanking count), a multiple logistic regression model was trained to distinguish TSS clusters that are likely genuine. The identification of these TSS clusters was performed per cell-type where cutoffs of at least 3 reads and at least 1 read with unencoded G were applied. Next, scafe.tool.cm.aggregate defines tCREs by extending and merging overlapped TSS clusters defined from different cell-types. This aggregation step only merges the clusters without pooling signals to generate new TSS clusters. Additional commands including scafe.tool.cm.directionality and scafe.tool.cm.annotate were used to calculate bi-directional reads in each tCRE and pre-annotate the tCREs with nearby GENCODE transcript model. The tCREs were then classed for the promoter types by intersecting with SCREEN cCREs, in an order of promoter-like, enhancer-like and CTCF-alone. If a tCRE was intersected with both promoter-like and enhancer-like SCREEN cCREs, the tCRE was defined as promoter-like. If no cCRE was found to intersect with the tCREs, these tCREs were defined as “unclassed”. These promoter types were directly transferred to the TSS clusters and transcript models. Expression level of tCREs was measured by CTSS of qualified alignments located inside the genuine TSS clusters, where the per-cluster signal was collapsed into per-tCRE level. The signal was normalised across all the samples with individual replicates by using the RLE method in edgeR. In the preparation of running SALA, strand-specific TSS clusters were merged if they are within 75 nt distance. If the signal from the merged clusters revealed bimodal distribution (>20% from each cluster), the merged clusters were split at the midpoint of the two summits. This extension was designed for concluding reads and reference transcript models into the same read class if their 5’ ends are in a proximity. The codes for running SCAFE in this study are listed:
