sec.p: To assess the content of these tCREs de novo identified from CFC-seq, ssCAGE from the corresponding samples were analysed. The reads from ssCAGE were independently subjected to the SCAFE pipeline or aggregated with the CFC-seq CTSS by SCAFE (Ext_Fig. 2a). The expression level shown in Ext_Fig. 3k was derived from the aggregated tCREs derived from both CFC-seq and ssCAGE signals.

sec.title: GC content, conservation, CpG island, TATA box and initiator
sec.p: In order to confirm the accuracy of the identified TSS clusters and tCREs, including their capability of initiating transcription and the precise position of the TSSs, different promoter sequence properties were intersected with the ex5_clusters using the summit (TSS) at the centre position. These ex5_clusters are strand-specific, contain xx TSS clusters on average and only have one parental tCRE.

PhastCon annotations (4way, 17way, 30way and 100way), 5-base GC content and CGI annotation from hg38 were downloaded from UCSC. The motifs of the TATA box (TBP: MA0108.3) and the initiator (INR: POL002.1) were obtained from Jaspar. The motifs were searched against the genome using scanMotifGenomeWide.pl of Homer v4.11 (Heinz et al. 2010). Summits of the ex5_clusters were extended 5 kb up- and down-stream and intersected with the phastCon annotations. The mean values per position were extracted for the positional plot. The mean value of 17way annotation of the 500 bp upstream the summit was used to represent the sequence conservation for each ex5_cluster. For GC content, summits were extended 5 kb up- and down-stream and intersected with the 5-base GC content annotation. Backgrounds with the same number of ex5_clusters were generated from hg38 masking all the exons from GENCODE v39 and all the ex5_clusters. For CGI, summits were extended 5 kb up- and down-stream and intersected with the annotation. The coverage of CGI for each region was extracted. To determine CGI-positive ex5_clusters, 500 nt before the summit shows > 200 nt overlap with CGI annotation with at least 40 CGI units. For dCGI, the same criteria were required for the 500 nt downstream of the summits. For TATA box and initiator motifs, summits were extended for 50 bp up- and down-stream and intersected with the Homer genome-wide results. If there is more than one occurrence in the 101 nt region, the ones with higher motif scores were taken. To determine TATA box-positive ex5_clusters, a TATA box with motif score at least 3 is found between -35 to -11 nt according to the first base of the TATA motif.

sec.title: Transcript model construction using SALA
sec.p: SALA is divided into 3 steps: features collection, transcript model assembling and gene model annotation. In the feature collection, the 5’ end clusters, 3’ end clusters and splicing junctions were collected from the reads. The TSS clusters and summits identified from SCAFE were applied directly. The 3’ end tags were collapsed into clusters by Paraclu with at least 3 tags in a cluster. Summit and signal were also defined for each 3’ end cluster. All the splicing junctions from the bam files after TranscriptClean were extracted. The max quality scores of the 6 nt surrounding the junctions were also extracted. The junctions from sample-matching short-read RNA-seq were obtained from the SJ.out.tab output from STAR. Additionally, the 5’ end, 3’ end and junction positions from GENCODE v39 were subjected to SALA. The 5’ end clusters were merged at a 75 nt distance. According to the long-read signals from the merged clusters, merged bimodal clusters (>10%) were splitted at the midpoint. The GENCODE 5’ ends were merged with these clusters with 75 nt. The 3’ end clusters were merged similarly at a 150 nt distance while GENCODE 3’ ends were also merged with 150 nt. The 5’ end clusters with SCAFE support or GENCODE support were considered as “confident”. The 3’ end clusters with paraclu support or GENCODE support were considered as “confident”.

For the transcript model assembling, every read subjected to SALA was assigned with a 5’ end cluster and a 3’ end cluster while every junction observed from the read was assigned with a junction ID. The reads with both confident 5’ clusters and confident 3’ clusters, and all the reference transcript models (e.g. GENCODE v39) were considered as “complete”. These reads having the same features (5’ end cluster, 3’ end cluster and all junctions) were grouped as a transcript model. The “incomplete” reads were first assigned to the transcript models generated by the complete reads, becoming a partial support of those models. The remaining incomplete reads will be grouped into independent transcript models. After assembling, the 5’ and 3’ ends of the transcript models were defined as the most common 5’ and 3’ ends revealed by the corresponding reads. The following commands were used in this study: Input files preparation:

sec.title: Filtering of confident transcript models
sec.p: All the Transcript models generated by SALA were classed using GENCODE v39 as reference. These classes include known transcripts (assigned with an ENST ID), novel transcripts from known gene regions (Novel isoforms attached to an ENSG gene ID), and novel transcripts derived from novel gene regions.

we removed the detected partial GENCODE transcripts and kept only the transcript models with their starting sites linked to the confident 5’ end clusters supported by SCAFE. Specifically for the novel isoforms grouped into GENCODE annotated genes, 5 supporting reads from each of the replicates and 10% transcript ratio from one of the cell types were required. For the transcripts from novel genes (majority are novel lncRNAs), no further filter was applied.

For filtering the raw TALON transcript models, we applied different criteria for different transcript classes. 1, for the known transcripts of GENCODE v39, no filter was applied. 2, for the novel transcripts of known genes, 5 supporting reads from each of the 2 replicates and 10% transcript ratio from at least one of the cell types were required while the starting sites of the transcripts need to lie inside the genuine TSS clusters or match with the starting sites of any of the known transcripts. Transcript ratio was determined by the full-length reads defined by TALON (iPSC = 75,456,042, NSC = 59,230,321, Neuron = 47,230,302). Transcript ratio for every single transcript model from the raw table was calculated as [number of transcript reads / number of gene reads]. 3, for the transcripts from novel genes (all these transcript models were assigned with a novel gene ID including the “Intronic” we rescued from the Genomic group), transcripts were required to have their starting sites lying inside the genuine TSS clusters. We did not directly require reproducibility from group 3 transcript models but rely on the reproducibility of the TSS clusters (SCAFE regression probability ≥ 0.5). The raw and the filtered transcript models are shown in Table S1 and maintained in the webpage for this study. Coding potential of all the transcripts were assessed by the Coding Potential Assessment Tool (CPAT v3.0.4) (Wang et al. 2013) with default parameters. For novel transcripts, CPAT score < 0.364 were defined as non-coding, in which transcripts ≥ 200 bp were defined as lncRNAs. For the Novel isoform and Genomic transcripts, lncRNA transcript was defined by 1, CPAT score < 0.364; 2, length ≥ 200 bp; 3, linked gene annotated as lncRNA by GENCODE.

At the gene level, novel genes were classed as non-coding if more than 50% transcripts were defined as non-coding. Non-coding genes with at least 1 non-coding transcript ≥ 200 bp were defined as lncRNAs, otherwise were defined as short_ncRNAs. The gene classes of known genes were inherited from GENCODE.

sec.title: Sub-classification of lncRNA transcripts and genes
sec.p: From the CFC-seq with 5 cell-types, we have detected 6,559 known and complete lncRNA transcripts and identified 115,275 novel lncRNA transcripts. We classed these lncRNA transcripts into divergent lncRNAs, sense overlap lncRNAs, sense intronic lncRNAs, antisense lncRNAs and intergenic lncRNAs in ascending order. Divergent lncRNAs: transcripts with their ex5_cluster summits within ±2 kb on the opposite strand of any ex5_clusters of GENCODE protein coding genes or pseudogenes. Sense intronic lncRNAs: transcripts that intersect with GENCODE protein coding genes or pseudogenes, with their TSS clusters summits and the whole transcript lengths lying inside the intron. For those transcripts partially overlap with exons are classed as sense-overlap lncRNAs. Antisense lncRNAs: genes with ≥50% of their transcript region overlapping with the gene region of GENCODE protein coding genes or pseudogenes on the opposite strand. Intergenic lncRNAs: the remaining lncRNA transcripts that could not be assigned to any of the above categories. For the classification of the novel lncRNA gene, the same ascending order for priority was taken. For example, if a gene included both sense intronic lncRNA transcript and antisense lncRNA transcript, the gene was classed as sense intronic lncRNA.

sec.title: Classification of ex5_cluster and transcript model into mRNA, p_ncRNA, e_ncRNA, CTCF_ncRNA and other_ncRNA
sec.p: The ex5_clusters were divided into 4 groups according to the promoter types, which were inherited from the tCRE as promoter-like, enhancer-like, CTCF-alone with ATAC support and unclassed with ATAC support. Only the ex5_clusters producing ncRNAs (> 50% read count) were included while the definition of ncRNAs were described according to the CPAT results or GENCODE annotation. Additionally, ex5_clusters producing GENCODE coding genes alone were grouped as a control. These resulted in 9,749 ex5_clusters with mRNA outputs, 17,045 promoter-like ex5_clusters with ncRNA outputs (p_ncRNA), 28,718 enhancer-like ex5_clusters with ncRNA (e_ncRNA), 194 ATAC-supported CTCF-alone ex5_clusters with ncRNA (CTCF_ncRNA) and 4,645 ATAC-supported unclassed ex5_clusters with ncRNA (other_ncRNA). The ex5_clusters linked to both coding (GENCODE) and non-coding (GENCODE or CPAT) transcript models were excluded from the analyses. Since we have only included complete models in this analysis, the transcript length and exon number were supported by our sequencing data. Conversely, some known and long RNAs (e.g. KCNQ1OT1, 91kb) that were partially detected by CFC-seq were excluded from the analyses.

sec.title: TALON and Isoquant
sec.p:
For comparison with SALA, we analysed the CFC-seq libraries (Neuron series and THP1-series) by TALON. Same as SALA, the bam files after TranscriptClean and TALON label containing only primary alignments were used as input for TALON with the same reference transcriptome (GENCODE v39). TALON internally excludes alignments with percent identity lower than 80% or coverage alignment lower than 90% of the read. After the processing by TALON, transcript IDs were extracted from the TALON database to include all those novel transcripts classed as ‘Genomic’ but excluded all transcripts with evidence of internal priming as determined by the fraction of adenines 3’ of the alignment in the reference genome. All the undetected GENCODE transcript models were also excluded to make it comparable with the SALA analysis. This dataset was termed “TALON_Raw”. In addition, “TALON_Read_filtered” was generated by applying a filter for the transcript models as having 5 supporting reads from both replicates of the sample. [1]

sec.title: Exosome sensitivity
sec.p: RNA-seq data of another clone of iPS cell (Yip et al. 2022) treated with knockdown of EXOSC3 and control was annotated by the transcriptome generated in this study using pseudo alignment of Kallisto (Bray et al. 2016). Exosome sensitivity score was calculated at gene level as previously described: (TPMExosome-suppressed - TPMControl) / TPMExosome-suppressed. Genes that were not detectable from these shortread libraries (sum TPM of 4 libraries > 0.1) or not detectable from the both the iPSC and chromatinbound iPSC CFC-seq libraries were excluded from the analysis. Exosome sensitivity smaller than 0 was considered as 0.

sec.title: Bidirectionality of tCRE
sec.p: Bidirectionality was acquired from SCAFE output for each tCRE. Qualified reads were used for counting the number of CTSS on both strands (Ext_Fig. 3a). The D was calculated as absolute difference of the forward and reverse counts divided by the sum of the forward and reverse counts. The tCRE was defined as bidirectional if D < 0.8, unidirectional otherwise. If the sum if the forward and reverse counts is less than 5, the directionality was set as undefined.

sec.title: Super enhancer identification
sec.p:
Super enhancers have been predicted based on the magnitude of the H3K27ac ChIP-seq signal from various studies (Hnisz et al. 2013; Chapuy et al. 2013; Wang et al. 2023). The histone mark H3K27ac was determined from iPSC, NSC and Neuron by CUT&Tag (Yip et al. 2024). Briefly, reads were mapped to hg38 human genome using Bowtie2 (v2.2.6). After removing PCR duplicates, the bam files of the two replicates for each cell type were subjected to MACS2 (v2.1.0) for peak calling. The significant peaks (p < 0.01) were merged and extended into a minimum window size of 150bp. The peaks were used as the reference loci for counting the read number from the bam files using ROSE (Whyte et al. 2013). The enhancer-like CREs overlapped with the super enhancer regions were marked as super enhancers. The number, activity and size of the SE were shown in Ext_Fig. 3b&c. [1]
ROSE_main.py -g hg38 -i [significant H3K27Ac peaks] -r [H3K27Ac bam file] -c [IgG bam file] -o [output folder] -s 10000 -t 2500

sec.title: Quantification of CFC-seq samples
sec.p: Bambu (https://github.com/GoekeLab/bambu) was modified to account for the increased presence of full-length reads and enhanced detection of transcript start and end sites. Traditionally, Bambu constructs read classes based on shared splice junctions. Now, we divide these read classes into subgroups by incorporating transcript annotations with refined start and end sites produced by SALA. Briefly, for each first exon of spliced read classes, the start positions of all exons in the provided annotations that share the 3’ splice site were used as thresholds for grouping reads. A tolerance of 35 bp was applied to each threshold to accommodate small positional variations, and reads were assigned to the largest exon division they matched. Reads longer than the largest annotated first exon were grouped separately. The same process was applied to the last exon, but based on the 5’ splice site. These modifications were implemented in the test_split_read_classes branch. To ensure Bambu recognizes these more granular read classes, we set the opt.discovery = list(min.exonDistance = 0) parameter, reducing the allowance for deviation when assigning read classes to reference transcripts before the Expectation-Maximization (EM) quantification. Additionally, due to the presence of overlapping transcripts from different genes, we preprocessed the SALA gtf file by performing de novo gene annotation using the assignGeneIds function from Bambu. This function assigns new gene IDs based on overlapping stranded exon regions, enabling the consideration of overlapping transcripts as a single entity during EM quantification. The quantification was run with the following commands in R:

[2] mcols(annotations)$GENEID = bambu:::assignGeneIds(annotations, GRangesList())$GENEID
[3] dir.create(paste0(results_dir,”/rcOut”), recursive=TRUE)
[4] se.new <- bambu(reads = c(Neuron_Series_bam, Monocytes_bam),

sec.title: eQTL and GWAS SNPs
sec.p: The eQTL and GWAS data were obtained from eQTL Catalogue (Kerimov et al. 2020) and CAUSALdb (Wang et al. 2019) respectively. For the eQTL data, a cutoff of pip >0.3 was applied to include SNPs that are putatively casual. This dataset contains 102,614 non-redundant SNP locations. For the GWAS data, credible set version 2.0 was downloaded and converted into hg38 by crossing over the rsid with the SNP 151 dataset obtained from UCSC (n = 710,172,836). The GWAS dataset contains 917,107 non-redundant SNP locations after converting to hg38. These SNP locations were intersected with the regions of the ex5_clusters and transcript models (exons). Ex5_clusters linked to at least one GENCODE transcript model were grouped as ENST, otherwise were novel. The transcript models were intersected as they were. The SNP locations mapped to the GENCODE transcript models were removed from the novel group to reveal only the additional SNP coverage from the novel entries. The SNP vcf files and the transcript models (novel and GENCODE v39) were applied to the spliceAI to identify the SNPs that affect the SJs. Only the SNPs that negatively affect the acceptor and the donor score by 0.5 were reported in Figure 6a&b.

To divide these results according to the enhancer structures (dCGI, CGI, Null and TATA), intersection was grouped at the ex5_cluster level. Exons were merged from the transcripts that are linked to the same ex5_clusters using bedtools merge. In order to obtain a normalized enrichment, “common_all_20180418” dataset downloaded from NIH was used as background (n = 37,302,987, unique SNP locations = 36,363,997). The eQTL and GWAS datasets were limited to this scope of SNPs (unique SNP locations = 81,782 & 878,835 respectively) The merged regions per ex5_cluster were intersected with the common_all dataset, the eQTL dataset and the GWAS dataset. Exons that were shared by more than one ex5_cluster were recounted. The results were normalized as the rate of hit compared to the background SNPs or as the number of SNPs per 1kb. For the rate of hit compared to background SNPs, ex5_clusters containing no background SNPs were excluded.

sec.title: Hi-C
sec.p: The cells (iPSC, NSC and Neuron) were cultured and harvested as described above. Two replicates of each cell-type were fixed by 1% formaldehyde and Hi-C library construction was performed with the Arima- HiC+ kit and the Arima Library Prep Module (Arima Genomics) according to the manufacturer’s protocols. The libraries were then subjected to Illumina NovaSeq6000 for sequencing with 150bp paired-end mode. In order to yield a higher proportion of aligned reads, we first trim the 6 bp from the left end of each read as suggested by Arima Hi-C data analysis and then trim the 70 bp from the right end of each read using the command line “seqtk trimfq -b 6 -e 70”. The remaining 75 bp reads were used for the nf-core hic pipeline v 2.1.0 (https://nf-co.re/hic/2.1.0/). Since the two replicates of the Hi-C libraries yield consistent results in a pre Hi-C processing based on the subsampled samples. The two replicates from the same cell type were pooled together for the final nf-core hic pipeline with using the following options:

The processed Hi-C data was transformed into valid genomic interaction pairs at 5kb, 10kb and 25kb resolutions. The statistical significance of these interactions was calculated using the Bioconductor package GOTHiC (version 1.40.0) (Mifsud et al. 2017). Intra-chromosomal (cis) interactions supported by at least five read pairs and a q-value (FDR) ≤ 0.01 were deemed significant for downstream analysis.

caption.p: a, Flow chart showing the pipeline of SCAFE in identifying genuine TSS, TSS clusters, tCREs and ex5_clusters. b, 73,328 tCREs were identified from CFC-seq using 5 cell-types. They were classified as promoter-like, enhancer-like and unclassed according to the epigenetic information summarised by SCREEN cCRE. c, tCRE from the Neuron series overlap with open-chromatin regions defined by ATAC-seq from the same sample. d, The epigenetic signals H3K27ac and H3K27me3 of iPSC were intersected to the enhancer-like tCREs. The enhancer-like tCREs were split into 4 groups as Bivalent (both H3K27ac and H3K27me3), Active (H3K27ac alone), Poised (H3K27me3 alone) and Others (none of the two). Qualified TSS were counted into the tCREs while >=1 count was considered expression from that cell type. The upper panel shows the percentage of all the tCRE that produce eRNA in each enhancer state while the middle panel shows a subset which is uCGI/dCGI positive. The lower panel shows tCREs with TATA box. e, The percentage of tCRE groups that is uCGI/dCGI-positive (upper panel), dCGI-positive-alone (negative for both TATA box and CGI, middle panel) and TATA box-positive-alone (lower panel). Statistics were performed by the Fisher’s exact test, where OR represents odds ratio. f, Number of tCREs identified as unidirectional (1D), bidirectional (2D), cell-type dependent super enhancer (SE) and typical enhancer (TE). g, Sequence conservation analysis comparing 1D and 2D enhancers/promoters, and comparing SE and TE, based on tCRE grouping. h, Identification coverage of TSS clusters by CFC-seq, CAGE pair-end (PE) and CAGE single-end (SE) along an increasing MAPQ threshold. The union tCREs of all methods at MAPQ=0 is set as 100%. i, The divergence, which reflects the evolutionary age of the repetitive element, was plotted against repetitive elements found in CFC-specific TSS clusters (or others) at MAPQ = 10. Except specified, all the statistics in this figure were determined by Wilcoxon test with two-sided setting, where * represents p < 0.05, ** represents p < 0.01, *** represents p < 0.001, n.s. represents not significant.

caption.title: Transcript models identified by SALA.
caption.p: a, Schematic of the pipeline post genome mapping. Three key features—5’ end, splicing junction, and 3’ end—of all reads were extracted, aggregated, labelled, and qualified. The 5’ ends were clustered into Transcription Start Site (TSS) clusters, with confident TSS clusters identified by SCAFE. Splicing junctions were compared with junctions from GENCODE (v39) and short-read sequencing of the same samples. Base-call quality for each junction was extracted and summarised. The 3’ ends were clustered into Transcription End Site (TES) clusters, with confident clusters selected based on the read count. Additional labels for the 3’ end included the presence of a poly(A) signal (PAS) and internal priming. These features, along with the reference transcriptome and all reads, were applied to assembling. Confident TSS and TES clusters acted as guiding features, while other features were used to label the transcript models. The method for determining the end positions of the transcript models could be chosen according to the data structure. The resulting transcript models were linked to tCREs (transcriptional cis-regulatory elements) with promoter-typing and filtered for downstream analyses. The final transcriptome was quantified using expectation maximisation in Bambu (Chen et al. 2023). b, Number of transcript models and gene models identified by SALA. Transcript models were shown in three groups: ENST (annotated transcript models from GENCODE v39), novel isoforms (novel transcript models that are grouped under GENCODE gene models) and transcripts from novel genes. The promoter types of transcript models were determined by their derived TSS clusters. c, Coding potential of the three transcript groups were determined by CPAT (Wang et al. 2013). d, All the ncRNAs in this dataset including detected GENCODE lncRNAs and novel ncRNAs were subclassed according to the genomic location of coding genes and pseudogenes.

caption.title: Factors that affect the transcript model of eRNAs.
caption.p: a, Transcript length and genomic range of different RNA classes grouped by extended 5’ clusters (ex5_clusters). b, The median number of exons of different RNA classes grouped by ex5_clusters. Percentage inside the plot represents the percentage of groups having more than one exon. c, Transcript length of e_ncRNA comparison across a series of enhancer properties: CGI (presence of CGI within 500 nt upstream the summit), downstream CpG island (dCGI, presence of CGI within 500 nt downstream the summit), TATA box (presence of TATA box 5’ location within -35 to -11 nt upstream the summit), directionality (unidirectional 1D or bidirectional 2D), super enhancer (SE / TE: enhancers that are clustered within the super enhancer regions defined from iPSC, NSC or Neuron, enhancers from the THP-1 series are excluded), conservation (using the 17way phastCon annotation, the mean conservation score of the 500nt upstream the summit, ex5_cluster of e_ncRNA having a score > median is assigned as “Yes”, others as “No”). d, Median number of exons comparison across various enhancer features. Percentage inside the plot represents the percent of groups with more than one exon. e, The transcript length of 4 different groups of e_ncRNAs while each feature is exclusive from the others: e.g. the CGI group only shows CGI positive without dCGI or TATA box. Null represents the ex5_clusters with none of the above features. f, Median number of exons of 4 groups of e_ncRNAs. g, Enrichment of CGI, dCGI and TATA box with other promoter features for e_ncRNA and p_ncRNA. Enrichment was tested by Fisher’s exact in two-tail. FE_logOR represents the natural log of the odds ratio. h, RNAs were grouped at transcript-level while the presence of poly(A) and at least one splicing event were determined for each transcript model. Transcript length was compared for each feature. i, The transcript models were grouped to ex5_clusters while the frequency of poly(A) were weighted with read count. The red dot represents the mean value. j, Exosome sensitivity was determined at the gene level using RNA-seq data with and without knockdown of EXOSC3 in iPSC and quantified by our novel transcriptome. The e_ncRNA genes were grouped by ex5_clusters and subgrouped by various enhancer features. The exosome sensitivity was compared for each feature. Except being specified, all the statistics in this figure were determined by Wilcoxon test with two-sided setting. Here, * represents p < 0.05, ** represents p < 0.01, *** represents p < 0.001, n.s. represents not significant.

caption.title: Splicing efficiency and 3’ cleavage site of non-poly(A) ncRNAs.
caption.p: a, All the splicing junctions (SJs) observed from the final transcriptome. Majority of them has been annotated by GENCODE (v39), while most of the others SJs are canonical. b, Schematic of determining junction splicing efficiency per junction and weighted splicing efficiency per gene region. c, Splicing efficiency of the junctions was summarised at gene level normalised by intron count (Methods, Fig. 5b). Gene models without SJ were excluded from the analysis. The included SJs were filtered by three levels (>=1, >=3, >=5) of occurrence (count of span + count of splice, for both donor site and acceptor site). d, Gene models were grouped by ex5_clusters where only ex5_clusters assigned with one gene model were kept. The splicing efficiency were tested versus enhancer structure (dCGI, CGI, Null and TATA) for enrichment. e, Same as d for the p_ncRNA group. f, Nucleotide composition surrounding the 3’ ends of poly(A) eRNAs and non-poly(A) eRNAs. g, RNA secondary structure obtained from RNAfold by submitting 300 nt sequence from the 3’ ends of poly(A) eRNAs and non-poly(A) eRNAs. The relative hairpin score was summarised for 100 nt surrounding the 3’ ends.

caption.title: Functional aspects of the expanded annotated sequence a-b
caption.p: The eQTL and GWAS data were obtained from eQTL Catalogue (Kerimov et al. 2020) and CAUSALdb (Wang et al. 2019) respectively while a cutoff of pip 0.3 was applied to the eQTL data. The SNPs were intersected with the exon, donor site and acceptor site from GENCODE (v39) transcript and the novel models from the finalised transcriptome. The SNPs from each dataset revealed in the plot are non-redudant. For the donor and acceptor sites, a cutoff of 0.5 measured by SpliceAI was applied. Percentage increase from the novel entries were shown in (a) while the RNA groups were shown in (b). c, The presence of eQTL and GWAS SNPs found in (a) were subgrouped for the e_ncRNA according to the mutually exclusive regulatory element of the ex5_clusters. The size of the ex5_cluster and the transcript model were normalised to number of background common SNP. d, Hi-C interaction at 5 kb resolution with FDR 0.01 and at least 5 reads was used to infer connectivity between ex5_clusters of ncRNA and mRNA. Only the ex5_clusters showing at least one significant connection were included in the plot where the median number of connection per ex5_cluster was shown. Positive interaction from any of the 3 cell types was considered positive. e, Fisher’s exact tests were performed to test the enrichment of different repetitive elements located in different e_ncRNA ex5_cluster groups. For the cluster region, 6 nt coverage was required while for the exon region 200 nt was required. f, The percentage and number of ex5_clusters and exon grouped by ex5_clusters intersected with different repeat elements. At least 6 nt coverage is required for ex5_cluster while at least 200 nt coverage was required for exon. g, Expression profile of TATA box e_ncRNA ex5_cluster across the 5 cell types. The heatmap was divided into LTR positive or LTR negative. h, Overall summary of the features of enhancer and eRNA grouped by enhancer structures. Except specified, all the statistics in this figure were determined by Wilcoxon test with two-sided setting. Here, * represents p < 0.05, ** represents p < 0.01, *** represents p < 0.001, n.s. represents not significant.
